Body:
I believe that the success of Esperanto relative to other conlangs is mostly a historical accident. Specifically, that when the Volapük movement schismed and collapsed after the third Volapuk Congress in 1889, there were then some thousands of people who believed in an international auxiliary, looking for something that wasn't Volapük. The first Esperanto book had been publisheed two years earlier, and so Esperanto was in the right place at the right time.

I'm not aware that the Esperantist movement did much active proselytising at this time.
